publication.title: Face Mosaicing for Pose Robust Video-Based Recognition
The CMU Face In Action (FIA) Database
publication.jconf: Analysis and Modeling of Faces and Gestures
publication.abstract: Our team has collected a face video database named the CMU Face In Action (FIA) database. This database consists of 20-second videos of face data from 180 participants mimicking a passport checking scenario. The data is captured by six synchronized cameras from three dierent angles, with an 8-mm and 4-mm focal-length for each of these angles. We performed the collection

publication.title: Detecting and counting people in surveillance applications

publication.title: What are customers looking at?
publication.jconf: Advanced Video and Signal Based Surveillance
publication.abstract: Computer vision approaches for retail applications can pro- vide value far beyond the common domain of loss preven- tion. Gaining insight into the movement and behaviors of shoppers is of high interest for marketing, merchandizing, store operations and data mining. Of particular interest is the process of purchase decision making. What catches a customers attention? What products go unnoticed? What

publication.title: Pose-Robust Face Recognition Using Geometry Assisted Probabilistic Modeling
publication.keyword: Face Recognition;Probabilistic Approach;Probabilistic Model;Texture Mapping;Pose Illumination and Expression;
publication.abstract: Researchers have been working on human face recognition for decades. Face recognition is hard due to different types of variations in face images, such as pose, illumination and expression, among which pose variation is the hardest one to deal with. To improve face recognition under pose vari- ation, this paper presents a geometry assisted probabilistic approach. We approximate a human

publication.title: Online Modeling and Tracking of Pose-Varying Faces in Video
Generic Face Alignment using Boosted Appearance Model
publication.keyword: Face Alignment;Generic Model;Image Alignment;Point Distribution Model;Shape Parameter;Ground Truth;
publication.abstract: This paper proposes a discriminative framework for effi- ciently aligning images. Although conventional Active Ap- pearance Models (AAM)-based approaches have achieved some success, they suffer from the generalization problem, i.e., how to align any image with a generic model. We treat the iterative image alignment problem as a process of max- imizing the score of a trained two-class classifier that

publication.title: Video-Based Face Recognition Using Adaptive Hidden Markov Models
publication.keyword: Face Recognition;Majority Voting;Temporal Dynamics;Unsupervised Learning;Hidden Markov Model;
publication.abstract: While traditional face recognition is typically based on still images, face recognition from video sequences has become popular recently. In this paper, we propose to use adaptive Hidden Markov Models (HMM) to perform video- based face recognition. During the training process, the statistics of training video sequences of each subject, and the temporal dynamics, are learned by an HMM. During

publication.title: Optimal Pose for Face Recognition
publication.abstract: Researchers in psychology have well studied the impact of the pose of a face as perceived by humans, and concluded that the so-called 3/4 view, halfway between the front view and the profile view, is the easiest for face recognition by humans. For face recognition by machines, while much work has been done to create recognition algorithms that are robust

publication.title: Boosted deformable model for human body alignment
Automatic facial landmark labeling with minimal supervision
publication.authors: yan tong,frederick w. wheeler,peter henry tu
publication.abstract: Landmark labeling of training images is essential for many learning tasks in computer vision, such as object de- tection, tracking, and alignment. Image labeling is typ- ically conducted manually, which is both labor-intensive and error-prone. To improve this process, this paper pro- poses a new approach to estimate a set of landmarks for a large image ensemble with only a

publication.title: Automatic Face Recognition from Skeletal Remains
publication.authors: peter henry tu,xiaoming liu,carl adrian,phil williams

publication.title: Face alignment via boosted ranking model
publication.abstract: Face alignment seeks to deform a face model to match it with the features of the image of a face by optimizing an ap- propriate cost function. We propose a new face model that is aligned by maximizing a score function, which we learn from training data, and that we impose to be concave. We show that this problem can

publication.jconf: IEEE International Conference on Automatic Face and Gesture Recognition
publication.keyword: Facial Expression;Linear Discriminate Analysis;Principal Component Analysis;Optical Flow;
publication.abstract: In this paper, we present a scheme for face authentication by using applying principal component analysis (PCA) to model variations. To deal with variations, such as facial expressions and registration errors, with which traditional appearance- based methods do not perform well, we propose the eigenflow approach. In this approach, the optical flow and the optical flow residue between a test

publication.title: Gradient Feature Selection for Online Boosting
publication.keyword: Computer Vision;Feature Selection;Learning Process;Weighted Least Square;
publication.abstract: Boosting has been widely applied in computer vision, especially after Viola and Jones's seminal work (23). The marriage of rectangular features and integral-image- enabled fast computation makes boosting attractive for many vision applications. However, this popular way of ap- plying boosting normally employs an exhaustive feature se- lection scheme from a very large hypothesis pool, which re- sults in a

publication.title: Principle component analysis and its variants for biometrics
publication.keyword: Biometric Authentication;Component Analysis;Face Recognition;Principle Component Analysis;Time Varying;
publication.abstract: Principle component analysis (PCA) has been widely used for analyzing the statistics of data. While applied to biometrics as a classification scheme, PCA faces certain challenges. In this paper, we present a number of modifications to PCA in order to meet these challenges. Using face recognition as an example, we show how eigenflow, PCA applied to optimal flow, enables us

publication.title: Video Motion Capture Using Feature Tracking and Skeleton Reconstruction
Video based human animation technique
publication.keyword: Camera Calibration;Computer Animation;Cost Efficiency;Human Animation;Human Motion;Image Sequence;Perspective Projection;Three Dimensions;kalman filter;
publication.abstract: Human animation is a challenging domain in computer animation. To aim at many shortcomings in conventional techniques, this paper proposes a new video based human animation technique. Given a clip of video, firstly human joints are tracked with the support of Kalman filter and morph-block based match in the image sequence. Then corresponding sequence of three-dimension (3D) human motion skeleton

publication.title: A new approach to retrieve video by example video clip
publication.abstract: The similarity measure between video clips is a key issue in videoretrieval. In the developing of our video retrieval system, wepropose a new video similarity model. In contrast to existingalgorithms, it proposes many influencing factors, such as orderfactor, speed factor, disturbance factor, etc, based on thesubjective visual judgement of human. So this algorithmembodies the degree of similarity completely and systematically.On

publication.title: Apply semantic template to support content-based image retrieval
publication.jconf: Storage and Retrieval for Image and Video Databases
publication.keyword: Content Based Image Retrieval;Feature Vector;Image Retrieval;Multimedia Information Retrieval;Relevance Feedback;
publication.abstract: Content-based multimedia information retrieval is the hot point of researchers in many domains. But traditional feature vector based retrieval method can not provide retrieval on the semantic level. Integrated with our image retrieval system, we propose a new approach to generate semantic template automatically in the process of relevance feedback, and construct a network of semantic template with the support

publication.title: Eigenspace updating for non-stationary process and its application to face recognition
publication.keyword: Activity Recognition;Face Recognition;Principal Component Analysis;Random Process;Stationary Process;Synthetic Data;
publication.abstract: In this paper, we introduce a novel approach to modeling non-stationary random processes. Given a set of training samples sequen- tially, we can iteratively update an eigenspace to manifest the current statistics provided by each new sample. The updated eigenspace is derived more from recent samples and less from older samples, controlled by a number of decay parameters. Extensive study

publication.title: Protocol Switching: Exploiting Meta-Properties
publication.authors: robbert van renesse,mark bickford,christoph kreitz,robert l. constable
publication.jconf: International Conference on Distributed Computing Systems
publication.abstract: As we see a growing variety of network and applica- tion behaviors, it becomes more important that protocols adapt to their surroundings. Building adaptive protocols is complicated, and therefore we have considered build- ing hybrid protocols that switch between specialized pro- tocols. In this paper, we show for which communication properties this is a correct solution, and classify these us-

publication.title: Fast protocol transition in a distributed environment (brief announcement)
publication.jconf: Symposium on Principles of Distributed Computing
publication.keyword: Adaptive Protocol;Atomic Broadcast;Central Scheme;Distributed Environment;Distributed System;Generic Algorithm;Group Communication;Localized State;Network Topology;
publication.abstract: Adaptivity is a desired feature of the distributed systems. Because many characteristics of the environment (network topology, active process distribution, etc.) may change from time to time, a good system should be able to adapt itself and perform sufficiently well under different conditions.Modern distributed systems are generally built from a set of components. Such a system has the freedom to

publication.title: Building reliable, high-performance communication systems from components
publication.authors: christoph kreitz,robbert van renesse,jason hickey,mark hayden,kenneth p. birman,robert l. constable
publication.abstract: Although building systems from components has attractions, this approach also has problems. Can we be sure that a certain configuration of components is correct? Can it perform as well as a monolithic system? Our paper answers these questions for the Ensemble communication architecture by showing how, with help of the Nuprl formal system, configurations may be checked against specifications, and

publication.title: Proving Hybrid Protocols Correct
publication.jconf: Theorem Proving in Higher Order Logics
publication.abstract: We describe a generic switching protocol for the construc- tion of hybrid protocols and prove it correct with the Nuprl proof de- velopment system. For this purpose we introduce the concept of meta- properties and use them to formally characterize communication prop- erties that can be preserved by switching. We also identify switching in- variants that an implementation of the

Orthogonal Neighborhood Preserving Embedding for Face Recognition
publication.keyword: Face Recognition;K Nearest Neighbor;Neighborhood Preserving Embedding;
publication.abstract: In this paper, we propose a new algorithm called Orthogonal Neighborhood Preserving Embedding (ONPE) for face recognition. ONPE can preserve local geometry information and is based on the local linearity assumption that each data point and its k nearest neighbors lie on a linear manifold locally embedded in the image space. ONPE is based on Neighborhood Preserving Embedding (NPE), but

publication.title: File-Based Storage of Digital Objects and Constituent Datastreams: XMLtapes and Internet Archive ARC Files
publication.authors: lyudmila balakireva,patrick hochstenbach,herbert van de sompel
publication.abstract: This paper introduces the write-once/read-many XMLtape/ARC storage approach for Digital Objects and their constituent datastreams. The approach combines two interconnected file-based storage mecha- nisms that are made accessible in a protocol-based manner. First, XML- based representations of multiple Digital Objects are concatenated into a single file named an XMLtape. An XMLtape is a valid XML file; its format definition is

publication.title: mod_oai: An Apache Module for Metadata Harvesting
publication.authors: michael l. nelson,herbert van de sompel,terry l. harrison,nathan mcfarland
publication.keyword: Digital Library;Open Archive Initiative;Software Package;Web Crawling;
publication.abstract: We describe mod_oai, an Apache 2.0 module that implements the Open Archives Initiative Protocol for Metadata Harvesting (OAI-PMH). OAI- PMH is the de facto standard for metadata exchange in digital libraries and allows repositories to expose their contents in a structured, application-neutral format with semantics optimized for accurate incremental harvesting. Current implementations of OAI-PMH are either separate applications that access

publication.title: Enhanced Kepler Framework for Self-Archiving
publication.abstract: In this paper, we introduce the Enhanced Kepler Framework,an evolution of the original Kepler framework whichimplements an OAI-PMH-compliant data provider for individualpublishers. The enhanced Kepler framework isheavily influenced by Fasttrack, a peer-to-peer network. Inparticular, we introduce the concept of buddy nodes andSuperNodes to improve scalability. We also propose enhancementsof OAI-PMH, the harvesting protocol used inthe existing framework, to support the

publication.title: Preservation and transition of NCSTRL using an OAI-based architecture

publication.jconf: ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries
publication.abstract: NCSTRL (Networked Computer Science Technical Reference Library) is a federation of digital libraries providing computer science materials. The architecture of the original NCSTRL was based largely on the Dienst software. It was implemented and maintained by the digital library group at Cornell University until September 2001. At that time, we had an immediate goal of preserving the existing NCSTRL collection

publication.title: aDORe: a modular and standards-based digital object repository at the los alamos national laboratory
publication.jconf: ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries
publication.abstract: This paper describes the aDORe repository architecture, designed and implemented for ingesting, storing, and accessing a vast collection of Digital Objects at the Research Library of the Los Alamos National Laboratory.

publication.title: Using standards in digital library design & development
publication.jconf: ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries
publication.keyword: Design and Development;Digital Library;Los Alamos National Laboratory;
publication.abstract: This tutorial will cover a set of Standards and defacto Standards that can play a role in the design and development of Digital Library applications. The Standards that will be discussed are the ISO MPEG-21 Digital Item Declaration, the ISO MPEG-21 Digital Item Identification, the ISO MPEG-21 Digital Item Processing, the Open Archives Protocol for Metadata Harvesting, the Internet Archive

publication.title: Pathways core: a data model for cross-repository services
publication.authors: jeroen bekaert,herbert van de sompel,carl lagoze,sandy payette,simeon warner
publication.jconf: ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries
publication.abstract: As part of the NSF-funded Pathways project, we have created an interoperable data model to facilitate object re-use and a broad spectrum of cross-repository services. The resulting Pathways Core data model is designed to be lightweight to implement, and to be widely applicable as a shared profile or as an overlay on data models currently used in repository systems and

publication.title: The multifaceted use of the OAI-PMH in the lanl repository
publication.authors: henry n. jerez,patrick hochstenbach,herbert van de sompel
publication.jconf: ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries
publication.keyword: Architectural Design;Declarative Languages;Digital Library;Indexation;Individual Object;Los Alamos National Laboratory;
publication.abstract: This paper focuses on the multifaceted use of the OAI-PMH in a repository architecture designed to store digital assets at the Research Library of the Los Alamos National Laboratory (LANL), and to make the stored assets available in a uniform way to various downstream applications. In the architecture, the MPEG-21 Digital Item Declaration Language is used as the XML-based format

publication.title: Toolkits for visualizing co-authorship graph
publication.authors: johan bollen,michael l. nelson,herbert van de sompel,jeremy a. t. hussell,richard luce,linn marks
publication.jconf: ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries
publication.abstract: Visualization eases insight into complex systems such as co-authorship networks. We present an initial deployment of an author navigator application for convenient visual examination of JCDL and LANL co--authorship networks.

publication.title: Arc: an OAI service provider for cross-archive searching
publication.jconf: ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries
publication.keyword: Digital Library;Lessons Learned;Open Archive Initiative;Relational Database;Service Provider;
publication.abstract: The usefulness of the many on-line journals and scientific digital lib raries that exist today is limited by the lack of a service that can federate them through a unified interface. The Open Archive Initiative (OAI) is one major effort to address technical interoperability among distributed archives. The objective of OAI is to develop a framework to facilitate the discovery

publication.title: DP9: an OAI gateway service for web crawlers
publication.jconf: ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries
publication.keyword: Deep Web;Indexation;Open Archive Initiative;Open Source;Search Engine;Web Crawler;Web Search Engine;
publication.abstract: Many libraries and databases are closed to general-purpose Web crawlers, and they expose their content only through their own search engines. At the same time many researchers attempt to locate technical papers through general-purpose Web search engines. DP9 is an open source gateway service that allows general search engines, (e.g. Google, Inktomi) to index OAI-compliant archives. DP9 does this by

publication.title: Repository synchronization in the OAI framework
publication.jconf: ACM/IEEE Joint Conference on Digital Libraries
publication.keyword: Distributed Search;Metadata Extraction;Open Archive Initiative;Service Provider;Value Added Services;
publication.abstract: The Open Archives Initiative Protocol for Metadata Harvesting (OAI-PMH) began as an alternative to distributed searching of scholarly eprint repositories. The model embraced by the OAI-PMH is that of metadata harvesting, where value-added services (by a "service provider") are constructed on cached copies of the metadata extracted from the repositories of the harvester's choosing. While this model dispenses with the

publication.keyword: Architectural Design;Declarative Languages;Indexation;Process Engineering;Front End;Los Alamos National Laboratory;Open Archival Information System;

publication.abstract: The field of digital libraries (DLs) coalesced in 1994: the first digital library con- ferences were held that year, awareness of the World Wide Web was accelerating, and the National Science Foundation awarded $24 Million (U.S.) for the Digital Library Initiative (DLI). publication.title: Representing Digital Assets for Long-Term Preservation using MPEG21 DID
publication.abstract: Various efforts aimed at representing digital assets have emerged from several communities over the last years, including the Metadata Encoding and Transmission Standard (METS), the IMS Content Packaging (IMS-CP) XML Binding and the XML Formatted Data Units (XFDU). The MPEG-21 Digital Item Declaration (MPEG-21 DID) is another approach that can be used for the representation of digital assets in XML.

publication.title: Pathways: Augmenting interoperability across scholarly repositories
publication.authors: simeon warner,jeroen bekaert,carl lagoze,sandy payette,herbert van de sompel
publication.keyword: Data Model;Heterogeneous Systems;Scholarly Communication;Service Architecture;Value Chain;
publication.abstract: In the emerging eScience environment, reposito- ries of papers, datasets, software, etc., should be the foun - dation of a global and natively-digital scholarly communica- tions system. The current infrastructure falls far short of this goal. Cross-repository interoperability must be augmented to support the many workflows and value-chains involved in scholarly communication. This will not be achieved through the promotion

publication.title: A Scalable Architecture for Harvest-Based Digital Libraries - The ODU/Southampton Experiments

publication.abstract: This paper discusses the requirements of current and emerging applicationsbased on the Open Archives Initiative (OAI) and emphasizes the need for a common infrastructure to support them.
